unnormalised: IIT Delhi's robotics dept. just bagged a major grant of Rs. 5 crores from the Ministry of Electronics and IT, boosting their research into agricultural robots. Prof. Amit Kumar, the project lead, said the funding will help them develop cheaper and more efficient robots for small-scale farmers in states like Bihar and UP.
normalised: I-I-T Delhi's robotics department just bagged a major grant of rupee five crore from the Ministry of Electronics and I-T, boosting their research into agricultural robots. Professor Amit Kumar, the project lead, said the funding will help them develop cheaper and more efficient robots for small-scale farmers in states like Bihar and U-P.

unnormalised: The goal is to automate tasks like weeding, spraying pesticides, and even harvesting, addressing the labour shortages faced by many farmers. Apparently, a prototype robot named 'KrishiBot' has already shown promise in initial field trials. It uses AI-powered image recognition to identify weeds and selectively spray herbicide, reducing chemical usage by almost 40%.
normalised: The goal is to automate tasks like weeding, spraying pesticides, and even harvesting, addressing the labour shortages faced by many farmers. Apparently, a prototype robot named 'KrishiBot' has already shown promise in initial field trials. It uses A-I-powered image recognition to identify weeds and selectively spray herbicide, reducing chemical usage by almost forty percent.

unnormalised: This news comes at a time when Indian agriculture is grappling with several challenges, including climate change and rising input costs. The KrishiBot project aims to mitigate these challenges by making farming more sustainable and profitable. The initial investment also covered the purchase of 5 Nvidia RTX A6000 GPUs for on-device processing!

The KrishiBot project aims to mitigate these challenges by making farming more sustainable and profitable. The initial investment also covered the purchase of five Nvidia R-T-X A six thousand G-P-Us for on-device processing!

unnormalised: According to Dr. Sharma, a senior researcher involved in the project, they plan to roll out KrishiBot to 50 farms in Haryana by Q4 2024 for further testing. They are also working on integrating drone technology for crop monitoring and soil analysis.
